messages: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:59): wonders what self-raising flour is in Swedish, and what grease-proof paper is
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (21:59): also wonders whether to cook today or tomorrow
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:22): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: grease-proof paper: wax paper?  or parchment paper?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:23): Um, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greaseproof_paper
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:32): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: self-rasing lour doesn't exist
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:32): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: gah,
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:32): you just have to use ordinary flour + baking powder
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:32): *gah
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:32): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: What's baking powder, then?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:32): Something quite obviosu
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:33): ah, ok
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:33): Greaseproof paper is something like Bakpaper
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:34): is proving how much baking he's done in the past year
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (22:35): I don't know the Swedish for "my oven's on fire" so if you reach that stage you're on your own
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:35): has concluded he'll just bake after lunch tomorrow
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:36): Well, it's a bit on the late side already, and it won't take long
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:36): (See, having lunch at $ridiculousTime has advantages
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:38): http://www.robglidden.com/2010/05/how-googles-open-sourcing-of-vp8-harms-the-open-web/
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:39): So is the argument here that we should put web video on pause for 10 years while stuff is developed?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:40): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: And now you're going to call me insane :P

1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:48): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: I'd like to believe that the dude recognizes that every solution is bad, and that he's merely pointing out the badness of the particular solution that Google chose.

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:50): It doesn't seem that way. "It is well known that many experts consider it now feasible to standardize serviceable royalty-free codecs." and "Google should get on board on this important trend, not undermine it"

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (22:51): This also seems to show a misunderstanding of how patent trolls work: "Contributing VP8 to a standards group with a strong patent disclosure policy would be a good corrective move; it would force lurking patent holders to come fully into the public."
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:51): Yeah, I'd just like to believe that.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:52): Truthfully he seems to be painfully naive.  I noticed that last one you quoted in particular.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:59): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9, a strong patent disclosure policy like ISO, which produced H.264?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:59): Disclosure isn't the same as licensing.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:59): Yup, I think he has a mistaken idea of what it means to "disclose" a patent.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:59): Patent trolls don't join groups with patent licensing policies.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (22:59): It can mean "Yup, we have a patent.  Have fun licensing it!"
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:00): Even in a group like the W3C, anyone with patents could always refuse to join the Working Group rather than disclose or license its patents.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:01): Assuming they're a member in the first place.

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:02): But I read another thing somewhere else. What if someone came up with a patent that turned out to be essential to h264, and refuse to license it. Could they shut down everyone using h264?
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:03): Sure, in theory.  You don't have to license your patents to anyone.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:03): It's unlikely that they wouldn't accept whatever payout they were offered, though.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:03): Also, we could just have H.264a released really quickly to work around the patent.
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (23:03): Plus there's H.265 one of these days.  So it wouldn't help much, I don't think.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (23:04): Well, the concept was that someone would do it because they wanted to give open video a boost by shutting down the best alternative
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:04): That would be somewhat hilarious, actually.
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:15): I submitted a comment to glidden's post expanding on what we're saying here.
